sentences_tone.text: A Trump Presidency Isn't All Bad News For Tesla - Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksA Trump Presidency Isn't All Bad News For TeslaNov.11.16 | About: Tesla Motors (TSLA) Aboutboul Management Consulting Follow Portfolio strategy, hedge fund manager, ETF investing, long/short equitySend Message|Management ConsultingSummaryShares of Tesla Motors are down about 6% since news of a surprise Trump win in Tuesday’s U.S. presidential election.Under a Trump administration, Tesla stands to lose consumer tax incentives as well as clean-energy subsidies which have allowed the auto manufacturer to keep costs competitive.Some of those blows may be mitigated by lower tax rates and cuts to manufacturing regulations as well as other possible incentives for U.S. manufacturers.The only certainty regarding TSLA is uncertainty.Shares of Tesla Motors (NASDAQ:TSLA) have been down since the results of the U.S. presidential elections hit.
The news of a surprise win by Trump likely wasn't the preferred outcome for Tesla given the president-elect's support for the coal and oil industries.
Trump is seen as likely to end subsidies for clean energy companies and it is unknown if he will extend current tax credits aimed at boosting incentives for consumers to purchase electric cars.
Furthermore, Trump's energy policy, although still not completely clear, will likely focus on more tradition non-renewable energy sources such as coal, gas and oil.
The subsidies are controversial.
Last Month, Robert Murray, CEO of Murray Energy Corporations called Tesla a "fraud" live on CNBC mostly due to the large amount of clean energy subsidies it receives.
A federal tax credit of $7,500 is available to all Tesla buyers and, on top of that, some states even offer additional incentives.

All this is coming at a time where Tesla's success hinges on the sales outcomes of its upcoming Model 3. Once Tesla's total vehicle sales hit the 200,000 mark, however, the tax credit will be phased out and that's expected to happen around 2018.
Some analysts predict Model 3 sales will not suffer drastically due to the end of the tax incentive, but it really remains to be seen.
Tesla is far less dependent on subsidies now than it has been in the past.
Despite that, an elimination or large cut in subsidies and a reduction or elimination of tax credits would likely be issues Tesla will have to confront sometime within the next 18 months.
Click to enlarge (Source: Bloomberg) Some other issues Tesla will have to deal with are uncertainties regarding Trump's Mexico policy.
According to Bloomberg, the Mexico policy could hurt imports from Mexico where Tesla produces its network of superchargers.
It also plans on buying lithium from Mexico for U.S. produced batteries.
So, Tesla could see the net costs of its vehicles for consumers rise at the same time its production costs rise.
That puts a fork in the road for Tesla's goals of bringing down the cost of its electric vehicles to that of its comparably equipped competitors.
On top of all that, Trump has vowed to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).
The implications that can have on the auto industry in general is uncertain.
Since 2010, nine different U.S. auto manufacturers have moved various aspects of their businesses to Mexico, totaling $24 billion in Mexican investments.
Because Tesla's operations and manufacturing are mostly done within the U.S., it remains to be seen whether it'll receive bonus points for its loyalty to American workers.
Tesla creates a number of manufacturing jobs in the U.S. which is likely to be seen as a plus to a Trump administration.
Tesla also stands to benefit from reduced industry regulations as well as a proposed cut of corporate taxes down to 15%.
Whether or not that will be enough to sway the odds in favor of the electric car company is yet to be seen and it does seem like a longshot.
When it comes to Tesla's future, there is a lot of uncertainty around how policy changes will impact the stock's performance.
Rising costs brought about by a decrease in subsidies will vehicle costs and the removal of tax credits will mean consumers will be paying $7,500 more for a Tesla vehicle.
That seems like bad news but consumer sentiments may change over time given the costs of solar power generation is starting to fall below that of fossil fuels.
Click to enlarge (Source: Bloomberg) Trump's proposed manufacturing plan for Tesla would benefit some of the company's other businesses.
Tesla has recently acquired SolarCity - a manufacturer of solar panels in the form of roofing tiles.

SolarCity's roofing brings an aesthetic quality to solar panels which, up till now, have bared no resemblance to traditional shingles deterring some homeowners from making an investment in power-generating solar roofing.
Tesla plans to begin SolarCity production in Buffalo, NY in 2017.
Trump's proposed import tax on Chinese-manufactured products would help give SolarCity an edge on its competition.
Shares of TSLA are down nearly 6% from the $197 they were trading at on Election Day prior to any voting results being substantiated.
The stock is down roughly 30% from its 2015 high of $269.34 per share.
What portions of president-elect Trump's will be put in front of congress and whether or not those measures will pass is still completely undetermined.
It's no secret that Donald Trump has had his issues with the Republican establishment and many of his policy ideas did not fare well with various republican senators and congressman.

The future of Tesla Motors stands to be impacted more so than just about any other U.S. auto manufacturer under Donald Trump, but there are still a few changes that may overall help benefit Tesla, including proposed cuts to taxes and regulations.
At this point in time, it's difficult to pinpoint exactly what will happen but, as I discussed, there are reasons to believe as Trump's policies become more clear, TSLA could plummet even further.
If you've been holding Tesla stock, you've been on a wild ride.
The only thing that's certain is that ride will continue into 2017.
Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours.
